articles.headline: N.A.A.C.P., Energized by Liberal Activists, Dismisses Its President
articles.snippet: Officials at the civil rights group said its cutting of ties with Cornell William Brooks after only three years was part of a “systemwide refresh.”
articles.abstract: Officials at the civil rights group said its cutting of ties with Cornell William Brooks after only three years was part of a “systemwide refresh.”
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The national board of the N.A.A.C.P. voted Friday to dismiss the organization’s president, Cornell William Brooks, after only three years, pledging a “systemwide refresh” at the nation’s largest and most storied civil rights group in order to confront President Trump more vigorously.

articles.headline: Trump Told Russians That Firing ‘Nut Job’ Comey Eased Pressure From Investigation
articles.snippet: The conversation reinforces the notion that President Trump dismissed him primarily because of the bureau’s investigation into possible collusion between his campaign and Russian operatives.
articles.abstract: The conversation reinforces the notion that President Trump dismissed him primarily because of the bureau’s investigation into possible collusion between his campaign and Russian operatives.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump told Russian officials in the Oval Office this month that firing the F.B.I. director, James B. Comey, had relieved “great pressure” on him, according to a document summarizing the meeting.
articles.byline: By Matt Apuzzo, Maggie Haberman and Matthew Rosenberg

articles.headline: At Fox News, Another Prominent Host Is Fired, and Another Week of Tough Headlines
articles.snippet: The dismissal of Bob Beckel, a host of “The Five,” is the latest setback for a network coping with a harassment and bias scandal and the death of its founder.
articles.abstract: The dismissal of Bob Beckel, a host of “The Five,” is the latest setback for a network coping with a harassment and bias scandal and the death of its founder.
articles.lead_paragraph: For Fox News, it was another unkind week in an unkind year.
articles.byline: By Michael M. Grynbaum and Emily Steel

articles.headline: Dubious Corporate Practices Get a Rubber Stamp From Big Investors
articles.snippet: Arconic, the industrial materials company that spun off Alcoa, has been treated with kid gloves by big asset managers. Thursday’s annual meeting could change things.
articles.abstract: Arconic, the industrial materials company that spun off Alcoa, has been treated with kid gloves by big asset managers. Thursday’s annual meeting could change things.
articles.lead_paragraph: Institutional asset managers, overseeing trillions of other peoples’ investment dollars, carry enormous clout across corporate America. They can use the power and weight of their clients’ shares in public companies to vote for change on crucial matters, like outsize executive pay and anti-investor antics in the boardroom.

articles.headline: Opening First Foreign Trip, Donald Trump Tries to Leave Crisis Behind
articles.snippet: Mr. Trump leaves as a newly appointed special counsel begins looking into any ties between Russia and the president’s campaign.
articles.abstract: Mr. Trump leaves as a newly appointed special counsel begins looking into any ties between Russia and the president’s campaign.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump embarked on Friday on his first foreign mission since taking office, beginning a challenging nine-day, multistop, multifaceted journey to the Middle East and Europe and leaving behind a capital consumed by investigations and intrigue.

articles.headline: TV in the Age of Trump: Musicals, Murders and the Military
articles.snippet: Network executives are rolling out several shows with a strong military presence, while also focusing on true-crime sagas involving the Menendez brothers and Gianni Versace.
articles.abstract: Network executives are rolling out several shows with a strong military presence, while also focusing on true-crime sagas involving the Menendez brothers and Gianni Versace.
articles.lead_paragraph: Musicals, murders and the military.

articles.headline: Scandal in Brazil Raises Fear of Turmoil’s Return
articles.snippet: At each major turn in Brazil’s long-simmering political crisis, secret recordings have produced one bombshell after another, tripping up some of Brazil’s most powerful politicians.
articles.abstract: At each major turn in Brazil’s long-simmering political crisis, secret recordings have produced one bombshell after another, tripping up some of Brazil’s most powerful politicians.
articles.lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Just a few days ago, Brazil seemed to be turning a corner. The stock market was soaring. Bankers were cheering. The nation’s cutthroat lawmakers were lining up to curb spending. Inflation had been tamed.

articles.headline: Saudis Welcome Trump’s Rebuff of Obama’s Mideast Views
articles.snippet: President Trump was received warmly in Riyadh by Saudi leaders who appeared to embrace an American leader intent on supporting Sunni Muslim countries.
articles.abstract: President Trump was received warmly in Riyadh by Saudi leaders who appeared to embrace an American leader intent on supporting Sunni Muslim countries.
articles.lead_paragraph: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia — With trumpets blaring, cannons booming and fighter jets streaking overhead trailed by red, white and blue contrails, President Trump arrived in the scorching heat of the Arabian desert on Saturday hoping to realign the politics and diplomacy of the Middle East by forcefully reasserting American support for Sunni Muslim countries and Israel against Iran’s Shiite-led government.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Peter Baker

articles.headline: The Conservative Force Behind Speeches Roiling College Campuses
articles.snippet: The Young America’s Foundation, a well-funded group based in Washington, is on a mission to “restore sanity” at schools by deploying provocative speakers.
articles.abstract: The Young America’s Foundation, a well-funded group based in Washington, is on a mission to “restore sanity” at schools by deploying provocative speakers.
articles.lead_paragraph: BUFFALO — “Let’s give it up for the racists that are hosting this event!” someone yelled, and the crowd roared, foot-stomping in unison, then breaking into song: Woody Guthrie’s “This Land Is Your Land.” One member of the audience held up a sign, “Queers Against Islamaphobia.” Another unfurled a banner: “Muslims Welcome. Fascists Get Out.”

articles.headline: ‘The Internet Is Broken’: @ev Is Trying to Salvage It
articles.snippet: The Twitter co-founder, Evan Williams, reflects on what the social media service has wrought on society and how he is trying to change things with Medium, the publishing site.
articles.abstract: The Twitter co-founder, Evan Williams, reflects on what the social media service has wrought on society and how he is trying to change things with Medium, the publishing site.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Evan Williams is the guy who opened up Pandora’s box. Until he came along, people had few places to go with their overflowing emotions and wild opinions, other than writing a letter to the newspaper or haranguing the neighbors.

articles.headline: Killing C.I.A. Informants, China Crippled U.S. Spying Operations
articles.snippet: At least 18 C.I.A. sources were killed or imprisoned in China between 2010 and 2012, one of the worst intelligence breaches in decades. Investigators still disagree about how it happened.
articles.abstract: At least 18 C.I.A. sources were killed or imprisoned in China between 2010 and 2012, one of the worst intelligence breaches in decades. Investigators still disagree about how it happened.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Chinese government systematically dismantled C.I.A. spying operations in the country starting in 2010, killing or imprisoning more than a dozen sources over two years and crippling intelligence gathering there for years afterward.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti, Adam Goldman, Michael S. Schmidt and Matt Apuzzo

articles.headline: How Rollbacks at Scott Pruitt’s E.P.A. Are a Boon to Oil and Gas
articles.snippet: The new E.P.A. administrator has a long, helpful history with Devon Energy, going back to his days as attorney general of Oklahoma.
articles.abstract: The new E.P.A. administrator has a long, helpful history with Devon Energy, going back to his days as attorney general of Oklahoma.
articles.lead_paragraph: FREMONT COUNTY, Wyo. — In a gas field here in Wyoming’s struggling energy corridor, nearly 2,000 miles from Washington, the Trump administration’s regulatory reversal is crowning an early champion.
articles.byline: By Hiroko Tabuchi and Eric Lipton

articles.headline: For 2 Experts Killed in Congo, U.N. Provided Little Training and No Protection
articles.snippet: With little training and no safety equipment — or even health insurance — the pair headed into a remote area teeming with militia fighters to find the culprits behind a massacre.
articles.abstract: With little training and no safety equipment — or even health insurance — the pair headed into a remote area teeming with militia fighters to find the culprits behind a massacre.
articles.lead_paragraph: Zaida Catalán was on to something, and it was making her jumpy.
articles.byline: By Kimiko de Freytas-Tamura and Somini Sengupta

articles.headline: Trump Softens Tone on Islam but Calls for Purge of ‘Foot Soldiers of Evil’
articles.snippet: In a speech in Saudi Arabia, President Trump spoke in measured tones far from his incendiary language last year and called for a renewed fight against terrorism.
articles.abstract: In a speech in Saudi Arabia, President Trump spoke in measured tones far from his incendiary language last year and called for a renewed fight against terrorism.
articles.lead_paragraph: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia — President Trump on Sunday pivoted away from his strident assessment of Islam as a religion of hatred as he sought to redefine American leadership in the Middle East and rally the Muslim world to join him in a renewed campaign against extremism.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Michael D. Shear

articles.headline: Networks Offer Taste of TV’s Ad Future. Marketers Are Hungry for More.
articles.snippet: At this year’s presentations of coming fall lineups, there were signs that the networks were doing more to embrace viewers’ shift to digital platforms.
articles.abstract: At this year’s presentations of coming fall lineups, there were signs that the networks were doing more to embrace viewers’ shift to digital platforms.
articles.lead_paragraph: America’s biggest television networks invited advertisers to New York institutions like Carnegie Hall and Lincoln Center last week, giving them an early glimpse at their fall lineups and treating them to lavish parties and a parade of stars including Stephen Colbert, Kim Kardashian and Tony Romo, all with the aim of attracting billions of dollars in advertising by the end of the summer.

articles.headline: No, Google’s Not a Bird: Bringing the Internet to Rural India
articles.snippet: A recent convert to the wonders of the web is trying to persuade his neighbors in a remote village that “the whole world rests inside the mobile.”
articles.abstract: A recent convert to the wonders of the web is trying to persuade his neighbors in a remote village that “the whole world rests inside the mobile.”
articles.lead_paragraph: TARADAND, India — Babulal Singh Neti was sitting with his uncle on a recent afternoon, trying to persuade him of the merits of the internet.

articles.headline: Pittsburgh Welcomed Uber’s Driverless Car Experiment. Not Anymore.
articles.snippet: Nine months after Uber rolled out self-driving vehicles in Pittsburgh, the city’s relationship with the ride-hailing company has soured.
articles.abstract: Nine months after Uber rolled out self-driving vehicles in Pittsburgh, the city’s relationship with the ride-hailing company has soured.
articles.lead_paragraph: PITTSBURGH — When Uber picked this former Rust Belt town as the inaugural city for its driverless car experiment, Pittsburgh played the consummate host.

articles.headline: Lack of Workers, Not Work, Weighs on the Nation’s Economy
articles.snippet: In Utah, the 3.1 percent jobless rate has helped drive up wages, and the biggest problem is no longer a dearth of jobs but of people to do them.
articles.abstract: In Utah, the 3.1 percent jobless rate has helped drive up wages, and the biggest problem is no longer a dearth of jobs but of people to do them.
articles.lead_paragraph: SALT LAKE CITY — Stephanie Pappas and her brothers built their roofing supply company in this fast-growing region by promising next-day delivery, but lately they’ve been forced to tell some customers that tomorrow is impossible.

articles.headline: A Vital Drug Runs Low, Though Its Base Ingredient Is in Many Kitchens
articles.snippet: Suppliers of a simple, critical medication — sodium bicarbonate solution — have run out, leaving doctors to juggle chemotherapy and postpone surgery.
articles.abstract: Suppliers of a simple, critical medication — sodium bicarbonate solution — have run out, leaving doctors to juggle chemotherapy and postpone surgery.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hospitals around the country are scrambling to stockpile vials of a critical drug — even postponing operations or putting off chemotherapy treatments — because the country’s only two suppliers have run out.

articles.headline: In Saudi Arabia, Trump Reaches Out to Sunni Nations, at Iran’s Expense
articles.snippet: President Trump used a speech in the kingdom to declare his commitment to Sunni Arab nations, signaling a return to a policy his predecessor rejected.
articles.abstract: President Trump used a speech in the kingdom to declare his commitment to Sunni Arab nations, signaling a return to a policy his predecessor rejected.
articles.lead_paragraph: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia — As voters in Iran danced in the streets, celebrating the landslide re-election of a moderate as president, President Trump stood in front of a gathering of leaders from across the Muslim world and called on them to isolate a nation he said had “fueled the fires of sectarian conflict and terror.”
articles.byline: By Ben Hubbard and Thomas Erdbrink

articles.headline: Caught in White House Chaos, Justice Dept. Official Seeks Neutral Ground
articles.snippet: Rod J. Rosenstein’s naming of a special prosecutor in the Russia investigation is typical of how the deputy attorney general addresses tough situations, friends and allies say.
articles.abstract: Rod J. Rosenstein’s naming of a special prosecutor in the Russia investigation is typical of how the deputy attorney general addresses tough situations, friends and allies say.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Last month, Rod J. Rosenstein, the deputy attorney general at the center of the crisis building around President Trump’s White House, gathered with federal prosecutors and law enforcement officials to bid farewell to his old job, United States attorney in Maryland, and celebrate his new one.
articles.byline: By Julie Hirschfeld Davis and Rebecca R. Ruiz

articles.headline: As Profit Dwindles, Ford Is Said to Replace Its C.E.O.
articles.snippet: Jim Hackett, who oversees the unit working on autonomous vehicles, will take over an automaker under fire over its stock price and stagnant sales.
articles.abstract: Jim Hackett, who oversees the unit working on autonomous vehicles, will take over an automaker under fire over its stock price and stagnant sales.
articles.lead_paragraph: (Editors’ note: Ford on Monday announced the replacement of its chief executive, Mark Fields, vowing to catch up in the race to build self-driving cars and define a new era in personal mobility.)

articles.headline: White House Moves to Block Ethics Inquiry Into Ex-Lobbyists on Payroll
articles.snippet: The Trump administration has disputed the authority of the top ethics watchdog to request the names of former lobbyists working in the White House or federal agencies.
articles.abstract: The Trump administration has disputed the authority of the top ethics watchdog to request the names of former lobbyists working in the White House or federal agencies.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Trump administration, in a significant escalation of its clash with the government’s top ethics watchdog, has moved to block an effort to disclose the names of former lobbyists who have been granted waivers to work in the White House or federal agencies.

articles.headline: Movie Ticket Sales Sagging? Time to Bring Out the Toys
articles.snippet: With DVDs fast becoming relics and box-office numbers stagnating, movie studios are looking to toys and other licensed products to raise revenue.
articles.abstract: With DVDs fast becoming relics and box-office numbers stagnating, movie studios are looking to toys and other licensed products to raise revenue.
articles.lead_paragraph: BURBANK, Calif. — The once-catatonic corner of moviedom dedicated to merchandise has suddenly come alive as studios — walloped by vanishing DVD sales and determined to keep fans engaged between sequels — look at themed toys, clothes and home décor with renewed vigor.

articles.headline: Trump Comes to Israel Citing a Palestinian Deal as Crucial
articles.snippet: The president’s effort will test whether a career of business-deal-making can be translated into progress in the world of international diplomacy.
articles.abstract: The president’s effort will test whether a career of business-deal-making can be translated into progress in the world of international diplomacy.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — President Trump began a two-day visit to Israel on Monday with a blunt assessment for Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu: If Israel really wants peace with its Arab neighbors, the cost will be resolving the generations-old standoff with the Palestinians.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Ian Fisher

articles.headline: Ford, Trudging Into the Future, Ousts Mark Fields as C.E.O.
articles.snippet: The automaker promoted Jim Hackett and vowed to catch up in the race to build self-driving cars and to bolster its conventional product line.
articles.abstract: The automaker promoted Jim Hackett and vowed to catch up in the race to build self-driving cars and to bolster its conventional product line.
articles.lead_paragraph: DEARBORN, Mich. — Ford Motor was the American automaker savvy enough to avoid bankruptcy when industry sales collapsed during the 2008 financial crisis. Then it rode economic recovery and cheap gasoline to record sales and profits. But what looks like success can turn upside down quickly in Detroit these days.

articles.headline: Citigroup Agrees to $97.4 Million Settlement in Money Laundering Inquiry
articles.snippet: The agreement resolves some of Citigroup’s most serious regulatory issues related to its profitable, but risky, business in Mexico.
articles.abstract: The agreement resolves some of Citigroup’s most serious regulatory issues related to its profitable, but risky, business in Mexico.
articles.lead_paragraph: For years, Citigroup employees feared that millions of dollars the bank was moving to Mexico might be suspicious. Yet in many cases, the bank did not alert regulators or step up its monitoring for money laundering, federal prosecutors said Monday.
articles.byline: By Michael Corkery and Ben Protess
